content:
That depends if the spam detection is being done by Thunderbird, or if the mail provider (hotmail) is doing it.

In thunderbird's account settings under junk you can set the address books which will be considered as a white list for junk mail processing. If the sending address is in the address book and it is selected for white listing, then Thunderbird will not classify mail from that address as junk.

What the folk over at Microsoft do with hotmail I have no idea. I gave up trying to understand their machinations years ago.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: For new suggestions for Thunderbird, please post to connect.mozilla.org. This forum is for technical assistance only. Thank you for developing new suggestions.
creator: davidsk

content: Is this an addon that you are using to minimize on close? If so, I suggest retesting with the addon disabled to verify exactly what is not working properly. Then, if there is a flaw (bug), you can report it at bugzilla.mozilla.org. If this is a feature request, it should be posted at connect.mozilla.org. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: I regret the inconvenience. This usually happens when a rogue antivirus program interrupts the update. Some have settings to allow bypassing email, and that should be pursued to prevent this happening again. The free Windows Defender (as of Win 10 and 11) does not cause the interruption. Now, on your problem, are you seeing any error messages? Can you receive messages? If seeing error messages, please post exactly what is in the message. Also, can you post a screenshot of the SMTP server settings? That is viewable at 'account settings' and scroll down left side to 'Outgoing servers (SMTP). Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: Ok, I may be wrong, but I am inferring that you are referring to threading. Try this: - highlight the inbox - click view>sort by and tick 'unthreaded' (if menu bar isn't visible, click alt key) - OR, click the icon to right of 'quick filter' above message list pane and click sort by unthreaded there.
creator: davidsk

content: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open profile' - now exit thunderbird - note the name of the profile, which ends normally in default or default-release - now, click back arrow to prior windows folder - you should now be at the thunderbird\profiles folder, listing all profiles - in each, look for abook.sqlite (addressbook) and history.sqlite (collected addresses) (A prior version, several years old, may be there and is called abook.mab and history.mab - not needed if you find the sqlite ones) - if you find the desired files you can copy them and paste into the current profile (the one I mentioned above to take note of) - restart TB and you should see the contacts.
creator: davidsk

content: First, many users (including myself) prefer the vertical view, but to each his own. That is why TB offers options. If you use that small icon on right side of tool bar (called the hamburger menu), select view>layout and tick classic. If that isn't visible, you can click the alt key to display the menu bar and from there you can select View>layout and make your selection.
creator: davidsk
